Package org.gearvrf

You need to understand key points of this package to create a GVRF application.

    A "post effect" shader is a GL shader which can be inserted into the pipeline between rendering the scene graph and applying lens distortion.

    Selectors for pre-built post effect shaders.
    GVRPostEffect.GVRPostEffectShaderType.ColorBlend
    Selects a post-effect shader that blends a color across the entire scene.
    GVRPostEffect.GVRPostEffectShaderType.HorizontalFlip
    Selects a post-effect shader that flips the scene horizontally.

    Name map for post effect shaders.
    GVRPostEffectShaderId
    Opaque type that specifies an post effect shader.
    GVRPostEffectShaderManager
    Manages post-effect shaders, for modifying the texture holding the rendered scene graph, before lens distortion is applied.

Package org.gearvrf Description

You need to understand key points of this package to create a GVRF application. The Activity that your AndroidManifest.xml file declares handles the "android.intent.action.MAIN" (android.content.Intent#ACTION_MAIN) must descend from GVRActivity, not directly from Activity.

Your GVRActivity descendant must create an instance of a class that descends from GVRScript and pass that instance to GVRActivity.setScript(GVRScript, String) (or to org.gearvrf.GVRActivity#setScript(GVRScript, String, GVRSurfaceViewRenderer). A scene graph contains any number of scene objects. Scene objects have an 4x4 matrix which positions them in the scene. Each scene object can have child scene objects: moving the parent moves the children, maintaining the children's positions with relation to each other.

To be visible, a scene object must have render data, including a GL mesh which defines the surface geometry and a material which defines the surface appearance by specifying a GL shader and its parameters.

Assets

Several classes in this package can load resources from either res/raw, using standard Android R.raw. resource ids, or from the assets tree, using assets-relative filenames. There are pluses and minuses to each approach.

Using assets has two benefits and one drawback. The first benefit is that you can examine the tree at runtime. This lets you write code that will load all the assets in a particular subtree, even if those assets weren't part of your project when the loading code was written. The second benefit is that you can build a sort of matrix of names, like

thisPiece thatPiece
thisModel models/thisModel/thisPiece.whatever models/thisModel/thatPiece.whatever
thatModel models/thatModel/thisPiece.whatever models/thatModel/thatPiece.whatever
The drawback is that you lose compile-time checks: a typo in an obscure branch of your code, or an inadvertently deleted (or renamed!) file may go undetected if you don't manage to test each and every branch of your code. All the methods that take an assets-relative filename will return null if the file does not exist or is not legible.

Using res/raw files is pretty much the mirror image: you know the file will exist, but you've given up on discovery and you've flattened your names a lot, even throwing away file extensions. Thus, the resource-id overloads are probably best when you only have a few of any particular type of resource; the assets-relative overloads start to make more sense when you have lots of any one type of resource and/or need to do runtime resource discovery.

Asynchronous Resource Loading

Loading an Android android.graphics.Bitmap to create a GVRBitmapTexture can take hundreds of milliseconds; loading a GVRMesh can take even longer. These are not operations that you want to do on the GL thread!

GVRF includes an asynchronous loading facility, which improves throughput in three ways. First, by doing all the work on a background thread, then delivering the loaded resource to the GL thread on a runOnGlThread() callback. Second, they use a throttler to avoid overloading the system and/or running out of memory. Third, they do 'request consolidation' - if you issue any requests for a particular file while there is still a pending request, the file will only be read once, and each callback will get the same resource.

The asynchronous loader includes a priority system, so that you can load resources that color lots of pixels before resources that only color a few pixels before resources that aren't currently visible. There are four main things you should keep in mind about priorities:

  • Priorities are 32-bit Java ints, but not every int is a valid priority. Priorities run from GVRContext.LOWEST_PRIORITY to GVRContext.HIGHEST_PRIORITY.
  • Priorities use numerical order: a 2 is higher than a 1, and will run first.
  • All async loading uses the same throttler and the same priority system: a priority 1 mesh will load after a priority 2 texture, even if there are no higher priority meshes in the queue.
  • Priorities only apply to enqueued requests! If the async loader is not currently servicing "too many" requests, any request will be executed immediately; if the async loader is currently servicing "too many" requests, all requests will be queued, and then serviced in priority order. ("Too many" is deliberately vague: the current implementation is based strictly on the device's number of CPU cores, but this may change in future releases.)
